description.text:
As the Bezier functions are essentially a development tool, I find myself in need of a 'debugger'.
This 'thing' is an update of the Bezier library.  The primary additions are a couple of debugging aids.  Specifically, the ability to draw the control points as a wireframe, and the ability to do the same with the quad lines that make up the actual surface.
I have also refactored the various files.  The maths.scad files contains some additional functions that were useful, including some more matrix routines (determinant).
This release does not require the granules functions at all.  So, there is a new file "Renderer.scad", which is meant to encapsulate whatever rendering routines you're going to do.
I've also started moving down a path whereby parameters to functions and modules are provided as arrays, rather than as individual parameters.  I'm doing this because OpenScad reads like a functional language.  As such, I assume that every function returns a meaningful value which can then be used directly by another function.  This makes tying things together very much simpler.
And finally, in the bezier and maths and Renderer files, you will find things like being able to get a quad by simply calling a function and passing in the mesh control points, and your 'u' and 'v' values.
I still have not solved the normals pointing in the wrong direction for all cases, nor the short leg syndrome on the triangles, but one step closer now.

1) Get the code
2) Study it
3) Do your own bezier greatness
4) Rejoice!

title: Samsung NX500 and Canon EOS M Gimbal

description.text:
I remixed this model and adapted it first to Canon EOS M and then to Samsung NX500. I can now fit both cameras on it. Keep in mind that the original model and thus this model too is a bit hard to edit. I uploaded Sketchup files so you can change them as needed. Notice that the "overview model" is for preview only so one can see how the built gimbal looks like. Therefore exporting STL files from "overview model" is totally discouraged. Use instead separate model files to change it or to export to STL. You might want to rotate some parts so they lay down on the printbed. I used these rubber dampers from Ebay to hang under part to the top 4 holders.
http://www.ebay.com/itm/10pcs-Anti-Vibration-Rubber-Damper-Damping-Ball-for-Gimbal-Gopro-DJI-Camera-/311703174366?hash=item4892f4fcde:g:Uj4AAOSwAuZX4fyo Pictures are from different versions of the gimbal as I have rebuilt it numerous times. ¨ Electronics
  • Motors: Dys BGM4108-130T on all three axis.
  • Storm32-BGC is used a s a gimbal controller with NT sensor modules. Allows serial connection of IMUs which saves the wiring a lot. Took me hours to tune it.
  • 4S Battery power coming from the hexacopter PDB

Notes: These are the setting that worked for me. You might find other settings work better. I printed in PLA first but it was not hard enough, gimbal got a lot of vibrations. Then I found the best material "proto pasta carbon fiber HTPLA" so I used it for the last build. 0.6mm nozzle.
Unified bottom and back motor holder-30% fill, all other parts 20% fill. 1.2mm top/bottom thickness
1.2mm Walls Note for myself: Params for cradle nipple-right that goes into bearing: wall,top,bottom 1.2mm, nozzle 0.6, 20% infill, speed 50

description.text:
I could not find the style and size thumbwheels I needed, so I scaled the excellent work of Workshopshed for a couple of American sizes.  
These fit nuts for a 1/4" bolt thread and 5/16" bolt thread.  The tool size for these nuts is 3/8" and 1/2" respectively.  
Thus, the 1/4" thumbwheel is the equivalent of a 3/8" socket, and the 5/16" version is the equivalent of a 1/2" socket, if used as a tool over a thumbwheel.   
Note: 6/8/15: I fine tuned the 1/4" size to be a more perfect fit.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/g022pOz7JGL
Lets you attach a 1/2" poly hose to a pump having a 8.6mm / 0.34in barbed connection.

I created this so that I could attach a 1/2" poly hose to a pump that had a smaller barbed connector. I put some super glue on it and slid it over the barb on the pump. Be careful not to break the pump's smaller barb off when attaching the hose as they are not very strong.  
Like most functional parts, print it with 100% infill.

title: Arduino Materia 101 - Fan Guard With Logo

description.text:
After noticing that dust tends to accumulate on the fan's "petals", I decided to make two fan guards for the extruder fan and for the X axis motor fan, with my logo on them.  
After printing, I painted the logo and one of the circles with acrylic paint and a gloss transparent finish.  
This guard fits a 40x40mm fan.

I printed mine in white PLA, with 0.2mm layer height and concentric infill. After printing, please note that you will need longer screws or bolts to mount the guard behind the fans.
Also, you might need to introduce very thin washers between the fan and the guard, to allow for more room for the fan to turn.

author: Groover

print_settings.Notes:: Support: no support except "Extender.STL", which isn't a necessary part

description.header: Introduducing 3DPILE - a 3D Printed Inexpensive Laser Engraver

description.text:
Special thanks to 3dprint.com for writing an article about my project.
http://3dprint.com/74957/diy-laser-engraver-3d-printed/ This is my entry for the LightItUp contest, because a laser diode is basically just a focused LED outputting one specific wavelength.
Here you can find the printed parts and instructions to build a fully functional laser engraver out of two DVD drives and some other electronic parts for just 20-50$.

description.header: Why is this project cool/something special?
description.text: You may ask yourself: Why is this project so cool? There is simply one answer. It's the price point, which makes it something special. You can build this amazing laser engraver for just as low as 20$, if you already have some parts at home and carefully source the parts. And it is just awesome having an accurate, 3D printed and accurate laser engraver for just 20-50$, isn't it?

I designed this project using SolidWorks. I tried to keep everything as simple as possible (almost no nuts, screws will create their thread) and I focused on the printability of all parts (all parts can be printed on a standard Makerbot Replicator). And I wanted to keep the cost as low as possible.

It works basically like a 3D printer, only that it does carry a laser diode instead of an extruder. You use Inkscape with a plugin to generate the files the printer uses. Then you just send it to the engraver and it will start the engraving process.
To show how it works, I have made a short video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mp3-OLcRL1w&feature=youtu.be
The costs of this project will be between 20-50$ depending on where and what you order and if you need to buy the DVD drives or other stuff.
• reworked the base cause it was too wobbly, now it is nice and stiff

• added an optional fan holder - useful for cooling your laser and blowing away the fumes (you will need an Arctic USB fan)
  • added a STL called "Extender". Use this, if you can't focus your laser, because the distance between the workpiece and the diode is too low
Simply drop a comment or write me a message, if you have questions! Always happy to help! :)

description.header: Safety first! Be very careful when working with lasers!

description.text:
• 2x Easydriver (eBay, about 6$)
  • 1x Arduino Uno/Nano (eBay, 4-20$ depending if it is a Clone or not)
  • 2x CD/DVD drives (one has to be a DVD writer, 20$ if you buy them used)
  • 1x laser diode driver (I got mine from this eBayer (super nice guy, fast shipping and nice service: http://www.ebay.de/usr/anomalytech?_trksid=p2047675.l2559) (10-15$)
  • 1x breadboard to connect everything (5$)
  • some jumper wires for the breadboard
  • some wires to connect the steppers
  • 8x M3 screws not longer than 20mm (2$)
  • 1x 5V power supply at least 1A (5$)
  • 1x housing for the laser (5$)
  • some nuts or some washers to put on the screws to fasten the carriages (1$)

• basefinal.STL
  • holder.STL

• FanHolder.STL
  • Arctic USB Fan (7$)
  • Extender.STL (use this when you are experiencing issues focusing your laser)
  • 2x M3 nuts, depending if you use the Fan and its holder (0.20$)
    • That's in total, if you already have the DVD drives, the cables and the breadboard 30$.

• Extrusion widh: 0.48mm
  • Layer height: 0.2mm
  • Infill percentage: 30-40% (the higher, the better)
  • Print speed: 30-100mm/s (depending on your printer)
  • Support: no support except "Extender.STL", which isn't a necessary part
Open the DVD drives take out the carriages and take the red laser out of the DVD reader/writer. I won't cover this, because this step is individual, depending on your DVD drive brand.
Screw everything together like on the pictures and mount the linear carriages.
Use a vice and a towel to press-fit the laser in its housing. Another way to do it is to heat up the laser housing (don't heat it up too hot or you will damage the laser) and then put the laser in.
Connect your laser driver to the laser. I can't give you instructions to this step, because it is too individual. Just look in the laser drivers data sheet.

description.header: Mouting the laser and the bed:
description.text: Glue on your bed to the carriage (I used an old credit card sized piece of plastic), and glue the laser diode to the carriage.

Wire everything up. I can't give instructions here, because everybody will have a different setup. I used an Arduino Nano running GBRL to drive everything. You can find wiring diagrams of GBRL online.
Use 53,33 steps/mm for X and Y and 100mm/s^2 for acceleration.
Download Inkscape and install this plugin: https://github.com/305engineering/Inkscape
Put on your safety googles and start working with your laser engraver.

description.header: One more time: You will be using a high powered laser. Be careful!

description.text:
Wanted a single sided spool holder to support different spool IDs  that would allow relatively quick changes and feed filament in from top of machine. Also wanted to teach myself some more 3dCad ;-)   
.

Uses 2 22mm O/D Bearings, 8mm Threaded bar attached to whatever you like and a 8mm nut to fit in the tightening knob.   
Hopefully bearing and nut will be a tight fit if not get your glue out.  If a little too tight use 2 nut and threaded bar to gently push bearing in.  
Printing at 0.3 layer height on the face plate will give lots of steps/diameters which will provide even better support for the spool  
The cone and faceplate can be used on most peoples existing 8mm threaded bar setup but I've included a arm for 8mm printer frame. My printer now has aluminium angle across the top for rigidity so I doubt the second arm will be of any use but its included anyway. The one with slot on end will require fastening to printer frame there is an hole for bolt, ABSOLUTELY YOUR CHOICE IF YOU TAKE A DRILL TO YOUR PRINTER

Remix of Elindsey's Theobromine Molecule with labeled elements.

WilliamAAdams suggested, quite rightly, that the various extrusion parameters I've been doodling with could be controlled by functions... and I pointed out that the thing being extruded could be any 2D shape at all.
As a semi-practical application of these two ideas, this is a four-blade propeller made by extruding the union of a square and four rectangles while scaling that union according to the cosine of the extrusion height (with some twist thrown in, of course).
The layers are 1/4 mm thick.

It took 2 hours on this recentish latop to render the STL, but you can probably live with thicker layers, which would render faster. Skeinforge sliced it with no problems. Play with the OpenSCAD script, or print the STLs directly. GitHub repository:
github.com/syvwlch/Thingiverse-Projects/tree/master/ScaleExtrudeHorns

title: NAVIO+ plus  Raspberry Pi2 case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the case for the NAVIO+ autopilot that I have made. In the pictures you can see that it is almost a perfect fit. In the uploaded version you can see the names of some of the input and output port that I did not print in my case, but just give it a try and print it.  
A few minor changes have been made to the case to ensure a better fit. Also, ventilation slots were added.
To put it together just use the 11mm spacers of the navio, but you will need at least 8 M2.5X8 allen screw/bolts.

comments.text: This is great, can't wait to test. Just sharing some initial thoughts... In the long run I think it may need to be tweaked a bit for cooling. I've put heat sinks on both the chips (one big chip on top and bottom with the Pi 2) so might have to extend or cut holes in the bottom and sides for airflow. It's summer now so I guess we'll see if there are any overheating problems. But perhaps that's not important considering the device is usually surrounded by spinning props, and flying around at high speed :-)

title: Prusa i3 plexiglas & wood case with printed accessories

description.text:
This is a cas for my Aworldnet A602 Prusa i3 printer.  
The front and upper parts are in Plexiglass, the other sides are medium wood.  
All accessories needed to complete the case are printed parts.  
=> I had a problem to upload the hinge file so please download the "All STL files.zip" file to have all the files <=

To perfom this case, you will need:
  • 3x 50cm x 50cm medium wood 10mm thickness
  • 1x 50cm x 51cm medium wood 10mm thickness
  • 1x 48cm x 50cm Plexiglas 5mm thickness

  • 1x 48cm x 49.5cm Plexiglas 5mm thickness

  • 4mm diameter 25mm long wood screws

  • 4mm diameter 20mm long wood screws

  • 10mm thickness foam sheet
    • All printed parts are printed with PLA, 0.15mm per layer, 25% infill. => I had a problem to upload the hinge file so please download the "All STL files.zip" file to have all the files <=

Yes, everything is inside the box.
But I puted vents holes in front of the ramps box and in front of the power supply. That is why there are vents grids with foam inside to lower the noise.

comments.text: Nice design there ! Thinking about doing the same :) By the way, does it really lowers the noise of the printer ?
comments.author: titi974

comments.text:
Yes, it really lower the noise of the printer. Of course you stil hear it, but it really lower the noise.
The main positive point in my opinion is to keep the heat. The heating bed need less power to maintain its temperature and I have no more problem when printing ABS. With the heating bed at 85°C, I can maintain 40°C inside the box and that avoid partially the warping effect.

description.text:
This face is part of a sculpting i did as concept art for a game project.   
My very first model for printing purpose, i hope it works :-)  
I used Sculptris for sculpting and Blender to clean up, prepare and export the mesh.  
Have fun and tell me if you've printed it! :-)  
NOTE: 3D Model has no color in it. Its just a rendering to show you the shape.  
NOTE 2: Fixed the scaling problem. Now its about 13.1 / 7.2 / 4.8 cm

I used Sculptris for sculpting and Blender to clean up, prepare and export the mesh. sculptris --.obj--> blender
blender --.stl --> thingiverse

Extruder which can be mounted directly on Diamond Hotend (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:720520).
Purpose of this is ability to print at least one flexible material in higher speeds and better results. Extruder is derived from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:835542. Designed for Prusa i3 Acrylic 8mm.
I created there some holes to be able fix it with zipties, it needs to be attached to X axis slider on top , it is quite heavy and gravity centre is not ideally placed. Setup is also compatible with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:780967. Motor came from NEMA17 Motor http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:67561/#files. This is my first thing in crazy 3d modeling SW OpenSCAD. WEIGHTS:
full loaded : 567g
original extruder : 464g
nema17 : 310g
nema17 low profile : 220g

printed with 0.5 mm nozzle and very bad ABS
It can be printed without support from Slicr3.

comments.text: Hallo.
comments.author: TT83

comments.text:
1.Spannung am Poti des Treibers auf ca. 0,7V einstellen.
2.Düse im heißen Zustand von OBEN mit einem 0,4mm Draht durchstossen (gibt es bei Conrad). Am Drahtende vorher den Grad entfernen!
3.Temperatur etwas erhöhen.
comments.author: TT83

comments.text:
Ich denke, ich hab jetzt das Problem beseitigt.
Die Motortreiber waren auf etwa 250 mV eingestellt.
Bei 650 mV hat der Extruder gepfiffen und nach kurzer Zeit selbst ohne Last Schritte verloren. Der Motortreiber war kochend heiss. Das Ramps wird jetzt mit einem großen Lüfter gekühlt und die Drucke sehen gut aus. Danke für die Tipps
comments.author: T-Bot

comments.text:
Die Antriebsrad ist etwas größer, dann braucht der Motor etwas mehr Kraft. Hast du einen Kühlkörper montiert?
Du kannst es auch mit einem DRV8825 Motortreiber probieren.
Ist das ein Teflonschlauch oder ein Pneumatikschlauch in deinem Video?
Mit einem Pneumatikschlauch aus PUR hat das bei mir nicht funktioniert.
comments.author: TT83

comments.text:
Auf den Motortreibern sitzt jeweils der mitgelieferte Kühlkörper.
Eben dieser Kühlkörper war kochend heiss beim Extruder.
Mit dem 80mm Lüfter über dem Ramps bleibt alles kühl und es rattert nix mehr. Gewicht vom gedruckten Teil entspricht dem von Cura geschätztem. Die Küchenwaage ist zwar nicht so genau, aber reicht dafür aus.
Auf dem Nema selber ist kein Kühlkörper, wenn du das meintest. War aber angenehm kühl, von daher eher nicht nötig.
Der Schlauch ist ein Pneumatikschlauch aus PUC.
Hab ihn zwischenzeitlich von ca. 70 auf 50 cm gekürzt und zumindest bei kleinen Teilen funktioniert es erst mal.
Nach Feierabend werde ich mal den Ramps-Deckel mit Lüfterhalterung drucken.
Das Teil ist wesentlich größer, mal schauen was dann passiert.
Bisher hatte ich keinen Deckel auf den Ramps.
Inwieweit hattest du denn Probleme mit dem PUC-Schlauch?
comments.author: T-Bot

comments.text:
Freut mich das es jetzt funktioniert.
Die Reibwerte zwischen Filament und Schlauch waren bei manchen Filamenten zu hoch und der Extruder schaffte es nicht mehr.
Probiere mal einen Teflonschlauch.
comments.author: TT83

comments.text:
Ich hatte mir einen Teflonschlauch bestellt. Gekommen ist irgendein dehnbarer Schlauch dessen Oberfläche eher die Eigenschaften von Kleber besitzt und bei190°C anfängt zu schmelzen. Bin da mittlerweile skeptisch, wo es denn echten Teflonschlauch gibt.
Der Deckeldruck is natürlich vollkommen Mist geworden.
Hat sich an einer Seite vom Bett gelöst und gewarpt.
Irgendwie hat er den 1. Layer gedruckt und die darauffolgenden in X & y etwa 5mm versetzt.
Sieht zwar extrem schlecht aus, erfüllt aber seinen Zweck.
Bei den Endkappen fürs Alu-Profil hatte ich anschließend keinen Versatz mehr.
comments.author: T-Bot

comments.text:
Hast du mal die Spannung der Treiber gemessen? 0,5V-0,7V
Mit dem Lösen von der Druckplatte hat wohl jeder zu kämpfen. Mal hält das PLA super, mal kann man machen was man will und es löst sich. Mit UHU Stick Klebestift habe ich ganz gute Erfahrungen gemacht.
Ein Lüfter für die Elektronik habe ich mittlerweile auch.
comments.author: TT83

comments.text:
X, Y und Z stehen noch auf ca. 250 mV und E bei rund 650 mV.
Ich denke, das Bett war nicht gut genug gelevelt.
Und der Versatz kommt bestimmt von meinem Kabelsalat.
comments.author: T-Bot

comments.text:
Ich habe heute mal von Hand das Filament durch den Schlauch gedrückt. Solange ich Druck ausgeübt habe, war der Faden gerade. Danach kringelt er sich leicht.
Ich hab auch den Schlauch samt Fitting vom Hotend getrennt und den Lagerhalter_L in die Luft gedruckt. Da hatte ich kein Überspringen vom Filament, egal wie ich den Schlauch verbogen habe. Danach mit Hotend nochmal den GCode ausgeführt und es springt wieder. Normalerweise drucke ich bei 190°C, mit 200°C wird es auch nicht besser.
Die Düse hatte ich mir vor dem Einbau unter dem Mikroskop angeschaut und vermessen. Sah gut aus und hatte 0,4 mm.
Viel hab ich damit noch nicht gedruckt und über die Glasplatte hat sie auch nicht geschliffen.
Kann es sein, das die Einkerbungen vom Ritzel am Fitting hängen bleiben?
comments.author: T-Bot

Mit welchen Geschwindigkeiten druckt ihr?
Ich komme momentan nicht über diese Werte:
comments.author: TT83

comments.text:
Normalerweise mit 80-100mm/s, kleine Sachen mit 30-50mm/s.
PLA drucke ich mit 210°C / 60°C direkt auf Glasplatte. Die Glasplatte vorher mit Scheuermilch oder 1000er Schleifpapier abreiben.
Ich hatte auch schon Filament das das sich hochzog und einfach nicht haften wollte, darum kaufe ich nur noch bei Filamentworld.
comments.author: TT83

comments.text:
Ich drucke auch direkt auf eine Glasplatte, hab sie mit Haarspray eingessprüht.
Vorher haben sich langsamere Drucker auch gelöst.
Den Objektlüfter konnte ich nicht nutzen, da er nur bei 100% läuft und ein Thermal Runaway verursacht.
Den Abstand Düse zu Heizbett hab ich auf Kontakt gefahren und dann in Marlin 0,2 mm in der Höhe abgezogen.
Die üblichen 0,1 mm Blattpapier haben nicht funktioniert.
Wie wechselt ihr das Filament? Hotend heizen und rausziehen hat mir schon 2 mal ne Verstopfung gebracht.
Getestet hab ich bisher E-SUN3D-SCHWARZ und 3D-Color-Orange, beide über Amazon geordert.
Hab noch eine Rolle BQ-WEISS gekauft, wollte ich mal testen.
Achja, und Kabel-Management muss ich noch machen.
comments.author: T-Bot

comments.text:
Haarspray ging bei mir auch nicht.
Thermal Runaway? Das darf nicht passieren. Hat der Fühler richtig kontakt mit dem Alublock. Bei den billigen Hotends ist der Fühler meist nur in ein Loch gesteckt.
Ich lade noch eine Düse für den Lüfter hoch.
comments.author: TT83

comments.text:
Der Thermal Runaway kam vom Heizbett.
Der Objekt-Lüfter bläst direkt darauf, die Temperatur sackt innerhalb kurzer Zeit um 3°C ab und das wars dann.
Da der Lüfter nur mit 100% oder gar nicht läuft, kann ich auch nicht runterregeln.
Hatte mir auch ein neues Hotend besorgt, da bei dem von Kolibri3D der Thermistor nur ins Loch gesteckt war.
Somit war kein Kontakt zum Heizblock gewährt, da weiss man nie, was tatsächlich für eine Temperatur anliegt.
Apropos billig - Kolibri3D-Hotend 18€ gegen 9€ Hotend via Amazon Prime.
Bei dem Hotend von Amazon ist der Thermistor von einem kleinen Messingblech umgeben und wird mit einer Madenschraube fixiert.
comments.author: T-Bot

comments.text:
Der Lüfter wird nur getaktet (PWM). Das machen die meisten Lüfter nicht mit und laufen nur bei 100%. Abhilfe bringt ein Kondensator und ein Widerstand die das Signal glätten.
Filamentwechsel:
Hotend auf 180°C vorheizen 1cm Filament mit der Hand durchdrücken dann schnell rausziehen.
comments.author: TT83

comments.text:
Einen 470mF Kondensator hab ich aus einer alten Platine ausgeschlachtet.
Beim Retract bin ich auch noch nicht zufrieden.
Habe von 4,5 - 5,5 getestet und zieht immer noch Fäden.
Ich werde erst mal die Düse drucken.
comments.author: T-Bot

comments.text: Also 50mm/s sollten min. drin sein auch ohne Lüfter. Aktuell habe ich eine Dauerdruckplatte (nicht ganz billig aber alle Probleme gelöst). Interessant wäre was für material (pla od. abs) und bei welcher Temp. du druckst?
comments.author: TT83

comments.text:
Drucken tue ich, wie oben schon aufgeführt PLA mit 195 bzw. 70°C.
Der Thermal Runaway kommt durch den Lüfter zustande, wenn er eine Weile bei 100% läuft.
Habe mittlerweile den Kondensator eingesetzt, der Lüfter dreht sich nun bei allen 255 Werten.
Der Unterschied zwischen 127 und 255 kann man akustisch hören.
Hab zum Test das Hotend direkt übers Heizbett gefahren und auf Betriebstemperatur gebracht.
Lüfter auf 50 und 100% direkt aufs Heizbett blasen lassen und es kam kein Thermal Runaway mehr.
Das Netzteil ist übrigens ein 12V 30A, sollte also bei einer Maximallast von 16A definitiv ausreichen.

comments.text:
Hi,
ich habe meinen Drucker soweit am laufen. Nun geht's an die Optimierung. Wie hast du die Achsen zueinander ausgerichtet? Vor allem die Z zu X/Y?
comments.author: smoki3

comments.text:
Hallo,
Alle Achsen müssen leicht laufen. Eine schwergängige Achse sieht man sofort im Druckbild.
Erst einmal alle Winkel des Alurahmens prüfen.
Die Stangen für die Z-Achse genau senkrecht am Rahmen ausrichten.
Die Stangen für die Y-Achse am Rahmen ausrichten. Zwischenraum zwischen Rahmen und Stangen beträgt 33mm. Damit laufen die Riemen sauber in der Flucht mit den Kugellagern.
Dann den Drucktisch mit den vier Einstellschrauben ganz runter stellen. In die Home Position fahren. Den Kopf per Hand über den Drucktisch positionieren den Drucktisch an allen vier Ecken so einstellen, das gerade ein Blatt Papier durchgeht.
Fertig.
Würde mich über ein paar Bilder von deinem Drucker freuen.
comments.author: smoki3

comments.text: Ich bin gestern von den LM8UU Linearkugellager auf die Igus Gleitlager umgestiegen. Nun habe ich das Problem dass Kreise nicht mehr rund sind. Meine Vermutung ist das die X und Y Achse nun nicht mehr senkrecht zueinander sind. Achsen sind soweit eigentlich leichtgängig. Ein wenig strammer als mit den Kugellager - gut möglich das die sich nich einwenig einlaufen müssen.
comments.author: T-Bot

comments.text: Überprüfe mal die Riemenspannung. Die Riemen müssen gleichmäßig gespannt sein sonst zieht der Schlitten schief.
comments.author: smoki3

comments.text:
also die Riemen sind gleichmäßig gespannt. Und es ist definitiv dass die X und Y nicht senkrecht zueinander stehen :(
Durch den Lagerwechsel sind meiner Lagerschalen auch leicht ausgeschlagen. Allerdings bringt es nichts wenn der Drucker aktuell nicht winklig druckt diese neu zu drucken.

Die Riemen müssen auch gleich lang sein.
Drücke mal an einem Riemen und beobachte den Schlitten. Du siehst er zieht schief. Jetzt weißt du welchen Riemen du entspannen und welchen du spannen musst.

title: Guitar Pick Holder v2

description.text:
Never lose your guitar picks again!
This is the latest version of my guitar pick holder.
Clip it to your guitar shoulder strap, then spin the wheel enclosure to open or close the inner compartment.

Print all three parts on a 3D printer in the default orientation.
Like so many of my creations, no support material is required. Press the wheel enclosure into the back plate, using a vice. Make sure to wear safety goggles. Lay your guitar strap over the back, then press the squeeze tabs of the clip into the corresponding indentations on the back plate. Spin the wheel enclosure to close and open the guitar pick compartment.

title: Parametric USB microscope (or anything) mount for PVC
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Yet another mount for cheap USB microscopes. I didn't like the ones already posted, since they either involved a ton of printing, had very complex assembly with precise tolerances, or relied on the the scope holder that comes with it, which I found to be the most finicky part. This design is very simple -- a coupler that grabs onto a 1" PVC shaft, with friction set by a bolt; this mates with a holder, also set by friction and a bolt. The scope is simply zip-tied to it, since it wasn't worth my time to design a perfectly intricate holder when two zipties and a half-tube do would the job well. The PVC shaft itself can be mounted any number of ways -- I went with a 3-way coupler and a few other bits of PVC. Total cost for tube and 3-way coupler was under $5. It's almost fully parameterized, but I didn't enable customizer since I didn't have time to clean up the code.

Mount a piece of 1" PVC vertically somehow -- you can lodge it in a block, 3D print a base, or do as I did, and use a 3-way coupler with more PVC to form a base.  
Slide coupler part onto the shaft, add 1/4-20 bolt and nut (or similar) to tighten.  
Interface holder to the coupler, add 1/4-20 bolt and nut (or similar).  
Zip tie the microscope to the holder.  I recommend mounting it upside down like the picture shows rather than how the SCAD design has it -- the SCAD is optimized for printing orientation.  
Slide and rotate scope where it needs to go. The End.

comments.text: Neat idea.  I'm not familiar with plumbing fixtures, but I guess you could fill the two 'feet' tubes with sand to give the base some weight, then seal the tube ends somehow - hot glue?
comments.author: MarkTheMorose

comments.text: You could, and you could seal them pretty easily with end caps, which could be attached permanently with a bit of PVC cement.

remixed_from.title: 2 Liter Bottle Holder with Funnel and Cap

description.text: Cause a chick's gotta drink ya know... If you Print one, Share a picture of your Make as a Thank You! Backstory: Some of the Ross School's Innovation lab students are raising chicks in the school's EcoLab and we needed a small water dish. We wanted a dish that the chicks would be unlikely to step in to help prevent their water from being contaminated. We wanted to use a standard PET plastic bottle (here pictured with a "SmartWater" bottle we up-cycled. Note: The smaller water bottles are a little more stable and less likely to leak if filled to the top (too much pressure in the big ones). You can see it in action (if they aren't sleeping) right now on the Ross School EcoLab's live webcam on the chicks. And if you don't see any chicks you can see a short video here: https://youtu.be/GzNiKLl6jKE

Some of my other projects: http://innovationlab.ross.org/urban/ Printed with equipment from the [Ross School's Innovation Lab](http://www.ross.org/innovationlab ). PS: I've pulled the OpenSCAD file until I clean it back up. It was derived in part from Sprue's bird feeder base but I used Laird's 2 liter bottle thread.

We've printed out two of these without support. One in PLA and one in ABS. Both with a high level of fill on an Ultimaker 2, 70% or better with a 0.2mm layer height.   
If you don't have trouble with liquid leaking out of any of your prints then use whatever settings you find work best.

remixed_from.title: Unicorn Slide-on Button Cover. Unicorn Magic is only a button away!

description.text: Wanted to make a cool, original Dr. Who themed bow tie that slipped over a button, and came up with this fusion of cool objects found on thingiverse. I don't like to think too hard on my fashion choices, and so the bow tie HAD to slip over a button. No assembly required on this bad boy, just print it and put it on. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/kpCWApbbdY3 Latest updated file Oct 9: Added more depth to the Tardis so the window details print cleaner when printing with lower resolutions. Increased the size of the light on top to print nicer. Shrunk the button gap so it fits snugly against a button and should be less loose.

Combined The twirl pattern from 3DWP (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:417374) with Wearable Bow Tie by Tolin02 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:518175) and added the tardis from NickRBrewer (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:33756) and the Unicorn Slide-on Button Cover by AndyP. Worked some magic in Tinkercad (my favorite cad tool), and now this exists! Enjoy! :)

comments.text: This design is amazing for so many reasons.  If I could give it two likes, I would.  First off, it's a cool, clever design that's very appealing.  But it goes so far beyond that - it's a brilliant example of what is possible in the new "internet of things" -- here you've taken several different existing designs and combined them into something unique and appealing.  This is so much proof of what the future holds for 3D design and at-home manufacturing.

This is a 'Teetotum'. It's like dice, but instead of rolling it, you spin it. This Teetotum can have anywhere between 5 and 12 sides. The number is set when you run it in OpenSCAD (it's somewhat parametric). Example .stl files include: 12 sided, Arabic numbers
12 sided, Chinese numbers
6 sided, Braille numbers The font is from Happy Numbers: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8691 This was inspired by the Teetotum page at Wikipedia: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teetotum The drawing of the TeeTotum comes from "Every boy's book: a complete encyclopÃ¦dia of sports and amusements", 1881, E. Routledge (editor), uploaded to Wikipedia by user Dicklyon Thanks to Linkreincarnate for suggestions and support and to syvwlch for explaining what 'parametric' means. See Also user phooky has made some Dreidels! (sorta like a 4-sided teetotum) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4922
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1421

Caveat: I have no way to test it. In theory, though: 
Step 1: Print the .stl file
Step 2: Glue the bottom part into the top part
Step 3: If bottom part won't fit, shave it down somehow (sandpaper?)

Geodesic domes - even people who don't want to live in one think them beautiful. Who doesn't admire Epcot's architecture?  
This is another hub to join the struts that form a geodesic dome. This one uses common drinking straws as the struts, and builds a dome about 3/4 meter in diameter.  
This design's distinctive feature is the hubs' swivel arms. Fixed-angle hubs can only be used in the architecture for which they were designed, but a varying-angle hub like this can be used in different geodesic dome designs.

Many geodesic domes are possible, but here's a simple plan: Print -
  • 20: geodesic joint - 6 sides.stl
  • 6: geodesic joint - 5 sides.stl
    • Purchase drinking straws and cut to length -
  • 35 straws at 208 mm ("long straws")
  • 30 straws at 180 mm ("short straws")
    • If your straws are not the same diameter as mine (23mm circumference; see photo), you'll need to customize the "straw_inside_dia" parameter in "geodesic joint.scad". Assembly, starting at the top -
  • See http://www.desertdomes.com/pictures/dome/2vdiagram.gif, which illustrates these steps.
  • Rule of thumb: 5-sided hubs always connect to short straws, never long ones.
  • Connect 5 short straws to 1 5-sided hub.
  • To each of these 5 straws, connect a 6-sided hub.
  • To each of these 6-sided hubs, add a short straw, opposite the existing short straw.
  • To each of these straws, add a 5-sided hub.
  • To each 5-sided hub, add a short straw on each joint. At this point, your assembly should look like Assembly Picture 1. You have used all the 5-sided hubs and all the short straws, and should have only 6-side hubs and long straws left.
  • Connect adjacent 6-sided hubs with long straws, elevating the center hub enough so things fit. At this point, your assembly should look like Assembly Picture 2.
  • Add a long straw to each open joint on the 6-sided hubs.
  • Where 4 straws point together, join them with a 6-sided hub, again elevating the more central hubs as needed so things fit. At this point, your assembly should look like Assembly Picture 3.
  • On each open joint of the 6-sided hubs, add a long straw.
  • Where 2 straws point together, join them with a 6-sided hub, again raising the more internal hubs so things fit.
  • Finally, join adjacent 6-sided hubs with long straws. Your assembly is now complete, and should look like Assembly Picture 4.
    • The axles on each hub have very small footprints, so sometimes one will come loose early in the print and ruin the print. To prevent that, you can use the "w(ith) brim.stl" versions, which have a larger footprint and so are more stable, but are easier to work with than Cura's auto-generated brim. Example geodesic dome calculator: http://www.desertdomes.com/dome2calc.html
    When using a calculator, keep in mind that the joints printed here add 30 mm to each straw's length.

The code produces an arrow with curvy edges. It does this by intersecting and taking the difference of 4 pairs of circles. The positions and radii of the circles are customizable.  
Recommended for use offline using OpenSCAD. See instructions for help configuring your arrow. Offline use can produce a 3D or 2D file.

The code below produces an arrow with curvy edges. It does this by intersecting and taking the difference of 4 pairs of circles. 2 circles form the tip of the arrow (set1), and 2 form the back of the tip of the arrow(set2). The sides of the shaft are formed by set3, and the tail of the arrow is formed by set 4.   
The circles are specified by a modified polar coordinate system called "easy_form" which is ={distance from origin to circle edge, radius of circle, angle between +x-axis and circle center in degrees}. This coordinate system is SLIGHTLY easier to get a grasp of entering values. Changing the first value will push a curve farther from the origin (the center of the arrow). Lowering the 2nd number will make a line more curvy (by lowering the radius of the circle it creates). Raising the 2nd number will make a line more flat (by increasing the radius of the circle it creates). Changing the 3rd number is how you get position control. The 3rd number is the angle that the angle that the line connecting the origin and the center of the circle will make with the x-axis.Both the first and the third parameters can be negative. Negative radii will fail silently.  
It is highly reccommended that this program be used in OpenSCAD and not customizer. There is no input checking, and a lot of edge cases where circles will not intersect. If instead of an arrow looking thing, customizer or OpenSCAD show you two circles floating in space, it means that the circles are not intersecting, and the program is failing silently. If you wish to make a 2D file, use 0 for the height (I don't think this works in customizer). Offline, the program will also suggest a filename based on your parameters.  
The last 4 functions in this program are used to calculate the points where the circles intersect, which is used to calculate the length and width of the arrow. This information is available through the echo function, and not visible in customizer. So if you want to know the dimensions of your arrow, use OpenSCAD.

author: adivacaru

description.text:
Happy Numbers 0.2 is a number system for use in OpenSCAD. I am releasing it into the Public Domain, so you can use and modify it completely freely. Most OpenSCAD number sets on thingiverse consist of a separate .dxf file for each number. Happy Numbers works differently. There is a single .svg file that contains a set of numbers in a grid of 'character boxes'. This .svg file has been converted to a .dxf file. Then, in OpenSCAD, you call the char() module; it 'selects' the number you want by using an 'intersection box'. char(1) is the first number, char(2) is the second number, and so on. Thus you can: Change the font more easily
Make your own number sets more easily
*Use numbers in scripts in new and creative ways Currently it has numbers for these scripts/fonts:
Arabic (LMRomansUnsl10 - sorta resembles Nixie tubes)
Chinese
Devanagari (Hindi, Sanskrit)
Tengwar (Tolkien's Lord of the Rings)
Braille If you have any questions, feel free to ask. Making new numbers with your own fonts If you just want to use this, you can skip down to 'Instructions'. But if you want to make your own kind of numbers, here is the method I used to make this thing. Step 1. Getting an .svg and then saving as .dxf The first step is getting the numbers.svg file to have the font you want. This can be as easy as opening up Inkscape and typing the numbers out. Or you could draw the numbers yourself, or find some on the web; as long as they are 'outline' shapes, it should work. To do the process in Inkscape, here are the basic steps:
  • Open the numbers.svg file
    0.1 Go to 'layers' and 'hide' the 'Grid' layer
    0.5 Delete old numbers text
  • Create new numbers text
  • Select all of the new text
  • Click Path/Object to Path
  • Click Path/Break Apart
  • Click Object/Ungroup
  • For each character do the following:
    6.1 Select the character
    6.2 Click "Edit Paths by Nodes" tool
    6.3 Hit Ctrl-A (select all nodes)
    6.4 Hit the 'insert node' button 2-3 times (slow)
    6.5 Hit the 'make straight paths' button
  • Go to 'layers' and 'show' the 'Grid' layer
  • Move each number so it fits in one grid box
  • Go to 'layers' and 'hide' the 'Grid' layer
  • File/Save-As/DXF
    • There is a great tutorial here (I skip the 'document properties' step): http://repraprip.blogspot.com/2011/05/inkscape-to-openscad-dxf-tutorial.html Step 2. Check alignment The char() module has some parameters related to the DXF file. They include the x & y offsets to the first 'character box', and the width and height of the character boxes. You may need to check and tweak these if you change the font or characters. This can be done by running the adjustment_table() module and then manually tweaking the settings in char(). Example screenshots have been attached to this project; there are two screenshots with 'unaligned' settings, and one screenshot with 'aligned' settings. Example An example usage of these numbers is here, in my TeeTotum: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8690 References Arabic, Chinese, Devanagari, Braille: Ubuntu Linux, Wikipedia, google image search Tengwar: http://www.acondia.com/fonts/tengwar/info/numbers.htm
    http://freetengwar.sourceforge.net/ Bugs & Drawbacks The numbers are currently only 1 through 12. You have to 'manually create' anything larger. These are not 'scalable' - they are made out of small line segments. If you blow them up too big they will be 'chunky'. In Openscad, if you don't have GL2 or whatever, the full array of numbers shows up in the preview, not just the char() you choose, making it confusing. When rendered, though, it comes out properly. Braille is not 'bubbled', it's flat cylinders. The Tengwar dxf file is too tall, fix with charh=9 (see scad code) There is no 'size' parameter; you have to use scale(). Using adjustment_table() with GL2 might be confusing

Step 1: Download happynumbers.0.2.zip file. Step 2: Open up the .scad file & copy/paste the char() module into your SCAD project code. Step 3: Copy the .dxf file you want to use into your SCAD project directory. Step 4: You should then be able to go char(2) and get a '2' in your project

title: Drilling guide for mounting IKEA ATTEST handles onto doors

description.text:
This is a drilling guide for mounting IKEA ATTEST handles onto doors.
The handles have two screw points at 123mm distance. The drill bit is 5mm.
This is labelled "Work in progress" because I noticed that the shortness of the wall on the long side allows this guide to flex and potentially misalign the screwholes on the door. I have made a new version of this guide and will update eventually. Also will upload the data for the distances of the centerpoints some day.. EDIT: The STL is of the new version with the full length wall. jpg. is of the previous iteration, which has been used successfully but I decided it flexes too much and may cause problems if not used carefully.
I am now printing this stl. and will post pics asap along with comments on usability. EDIT: Uploaded pics of the new version (the stl. available for download). The sequence should illustrate how this thing works. There is no picture of the drilling process because I only have two hands :( But the final pic should show the handle installed like it should be. EDIT: Uploaded stl. for guide for drilling holes onto drawers (only one corner).
Eyeball centerpoint and stick a small slice of masking tape onto edge of drawer. Measure centerpoint and mark with pen. Place drawer guide onto centerpoint. See your mark through small semicircular hole. Drill like it's 1999!
Mount handles and rule the world. This thing will no longer be work in progress and I will no longer update since I've done my bit and mounted all the handles in our kitchen :D
Use, modify, win! I drew a blank on tags, so relevant suggestions are welcome so that this thing can be found by those who need it.

This thing should print with the large area to the work bed and walls rising (so no overhangs or support needed). This is what I had when I printed:
; layer_height = 0.35
; perimeters = 3
; top_solid_layers = 3
; bottom_solid_layers = 3
; fill_density = 0.4
; perimeter_speed = 30
; infill_speed = 60
; travel_speed = 130
; scale = 1
; nozzle_diameter = 0.35
; filament_diameter = 3
; extrusion_multiplier = 1
; perimeters extrusion width = 0.37mm
; infill extrusion width = 0.37mm
; first layer extrusion width = 0.70mm Place guide so that the drill holes are on the face of the door and the walls are tight against the edge of the door. (if you use this short walled piece make sure the guide is straight and not flexing) Drill holes. Screw in handles. Open and close door with glee!

comments.text: Quite nice! I read that the drill bit should be 4.8 mm (3/16") but I was able to use a 4.5 mm drill bit. A 5 mm drill bit should also work just fine, it would give a tiny bit more of a wiggle, but that can always be fixed with a drop of superglue. IKEA does sell a drilling guide but it costs $2.95. Making our own is very handy!

author: JakesterDS

title: M3 T-Slot Insert for 2020 extrusions w. 5 mm slots

description.text:
In the middle of my delta printer build (custom variant of the Mini Kossel) I realized that I was running out of t-slot inserts. Looking to buy some I either had to pay way too much for the delivery, or buy them from China and wait for 2 weeks. No fun. What I do have a lot of are common nuts and washers, so I made my own inserts instead. Works like a charm! The M3 nut and M4 washer (dia. 8.9mm) snaps right in and takes all of the axial load, the printed parts just makes the insert easy to mount and prevents the nut from turning.  
I use 2020 extrusions with 5 mm slots from Motedis, but I am sure these can fit similar extrusions as well. Remember to print the inserts either with the nut+washer side facing upwards, or standing up. The .stl is not oriented correctly, will fix this soon..

Pretty small part, so a reasonably good calibrated printer is ofc preferred. I would also recommend printing them at pretty fine settings. 30 mm/s at 0.15 mm layers was a good mix between quality and speed on my printrbot simple metal (4 minutes / insert).
  • Print (nut/washer side facing up, or standing) without support
  • Insert M3 hex nut, use pliers if needed
  • Insert M4 washer, use pliers if needed
  • BUILD!

comments.text: It's better to print it flipped around XY. In this case no support is required at all.

The idea of a chalk outline is an old one and seems deeply ingrained on the public's psyche. Completely ignoring the usual reticence around dead people and anything to do with them, I have trivialised it to the point of being a nifty little keyring! Initial product reviews are promising:
"Hey cool, did you make that?" - Friend at work.
"How long did you spend on that?" - About 5 minutes, friend at uni.
"OMG! WTF?! GTFO!! I'm calling the cops!" - Person whose house I walked into accidently.
"Just keep emptying out your pockets please." - Cop.
In summary, 3/4 of people who saw it were interested in my new keyring, one to the point where they called a friend!

• Make with 3D printer or laser cutter.
  • Attach to Keyring (see photo for completed assembly)
  • Feel ever-so-slightly squeamish every time you look at the outline of Mr Chalk, but take comfort in the fact that it was in one piece so at least his death wasn't too terrible.

author: engst03

title: Lasercut Birdhouse
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Create safe homes for the birds in your neighborhood using this customizable birdhouse design. The birdhouses shown here are just the right for the sparrows in our yard. But you can use 123D Make to scale it for the birds around you. Choose the linear or radial interlocked panel options. Rotate the base degrees along the X axis to change the overall look. Add more panels to provide more protection from eagles, hawks, owls or other local predators. Spray paint the panels before assembly to match or contrast with other elements of your landscape.   
Don't have a lasercutter? Use the enclosed STL to 3D print one.  
This is a great gift idea for any nature lover.

The enclosed STL file was created in a modeling app then imported into 123D Make. That was played with to arrange the panels to balance its size, appearance and openness, and to fit in my laser's bed. The version shown was burned on a Full Spectrum Gen5 Hobby laser cutter from a sheet of 0.177" Baltic Birch plywood. The material you use will almost certainly have a different thickness. So be sure to adjust the cut width in the 123D Make file and export your own cut plans. Use the enclosed cut plans only if your material stock is also 0.177" (+/- 0.01"). For the linear birdhouse design I drilled a small hole in the top to allow a string to pass through. I tied a bicycle tube set ring at the end of the string on the inside of the birdhouse.

title: Paintball Muzzle Brake - Barrett M82 .50 Cal Sniper replica

description.text:
This is a replica of the Barrett M82 50 caliber sniper rifle muzzle brake.
It has a 1" inner diameter to fit most standard paintball marker barrels.
Pictured on my TAR-68 sniper. Visit FreshPrints3D.com to see more!

Print in whatever orientation you think your printer can handle. I have good success with printing flat and bridging the gaps. Recommended Print Settings:
Layer height: 0.2mm
Shells: 3 minimum
Infill: 20%+ To instal on your paintball gun:
Wrap a few layers of electrical tape around the tip of your barrel, then twist the muzzle brake on. This muzzle brake is designed with a 1" inner diameter to fit most paintball barrels.
It should push-fit snugly onto the tip of your barrel with a layer or two of electrical tape. Visit FreshPrints3D.com to see more 3D printed paintball gear.

comments.author: shadow187mdk

comments.text:
This should fit pretty much any paintball gun with a normal sized barrel.
If you have a barrel that is less than 1" diameter, you can just scale the model down accordingly!

Thanks to dino-girl for uploading the DXF file fo this design.
I imported the DXF into Solidworks 2010, cleaned it up as the imports aren't always 100%, and saved each of the body parts as a seperate file as the DXF file had it all in one.
I then checked for thickness of the parts by looking at the width of the connecting slots and modified my files accordingly.

After printing you'll probably have to do some cleanup of the connecting slots so the parts go together tightly but with ease.
There are 25 parts files to this Mantis. Some seem like duplicate parts but are in fact slightly different.
I printed them all WITHOUT support purely to get the parts smooth both sides and have much less cleaning work to do.

author: frank1927

title: Underhood Mount For Smoke Signal Detector

description.text: The Smoke Signal was a Kickstarter project about a year ago. It's just a smoke detector wired to a power cut-off switch intended for use with 3D printers, Rather than having the sensor sitting near the printer, I wanted it mounted inside the hood of my Replicator, but I also wanted it removable so that the hood could still be removed easily. This Thing is just a simple card and slot that accomplishes this.

Nothing to it.  Print the two pieces, no special settings.  The card glues to the back side of the sensor with acetone.  Take the time to get it centered nicely and note that one edge is beveled for easier entry into the slot of the holder.  The holder part mounted to the top inside center of my hood (or wherever you want to put it) with two M3-10 screws and nuts.  
Yeah, it't going to get warm at the top of the hood, so I wonder about the survive ability of the sensor electronics.  But then, it is a smoke detector - I figure it should be designed for elevated temps.  I'll need to remember to test it on a regular schedule.  
Unfortunately there appears to be no indication that the original Kickstarter author has continued to market the Smoke Signal.  However, it's still a good idea, and you should be able to put something very similar together with some off the shelf parts.

The Filacleaner is designed to remove any impurities (dust, etc) before the filament reaches the extruder. For the filter, I cut out a piece
of foam from a cheap foam brush I bought from Hobby Lobby. This comes in two (2) pieces- one is the body of the unit, and the other is the top. The "Top" is a loose fit on the base to allow for easy
access to the filter. Unlike other designs which are spring loaded, the FilaCleaner uses the walls of itself to press the filter against the filament to ensure
reliable filtering of the filament. This FilaCleaner was made with FreeCad.

I printed this out reliably with PLA and these settings: Layer Height = 0.2mm
Cooling = 100%
No Raft
Skirt perimeters = 3
Infill = 35% NOTE I would highly suggest flipping the body 180 degrees to get
rid of the need for support material completely! If you want a snug fit between the top and the body of the filter,
scaling the object up 1.5% makes it a tighter fit. When you finish printing the filter out and add your filtration material, make sure that the filament is snug against all four sides (but not too tight) to ensure proper filtering.

title: badBrick - Speaker Case for Vifa TC6FD00-04 2" Woofer

description.text:
Fits 1 (one)  2" Speaker in a compatible mount Brick.  This mount is intended for a Vifa TC6FD00-04 2"  Woofer  
The case itself can be stand alone or mounted. The (6) mount holes also fit the round Lego shaft pegs in technic kits.  
This Case is also compatible with other generic 2 Inch speakers, we just optimized it for the Vifa because its a good quality speaker for its size and price.  
If you don't have a 3D printer but you're interested in getting one of these we can print you one at badbrick.com/catalog

In MakerWare, I modify the "Medium" settings: For the Top and Base of the Case:
Quality: Layer Height = 0.2 and I increase the temp to 240C to let the little larger prints fuse better. For the Face Plate Covers I change the Layer Height = 0.16 because MakerWare would error out on the print even though the gcode would verify. All other defaults are the same.

title: Front plate and strain relief for Sommer Cable Stagebox 32 Channel MKII

description.text:
This thing is a front mask with throughput for a round cable (24,5mm) for the Sommer Cable Stagebox 32 Channel MKII.
The second file is half of the cable strain relief system.
Should be a snug fit.
It was made in a hurry for a pal who was building his practice/demostudio and I failed to take photos. I'll go by his studio one day and take the pics...

Print one or two frontpanels. Print two strain reliefs. If you print two faceplates glue them back to back. Then glue the flange of one of the strain reliefs to the through hole of the faceplate.
Now the assembly should be screwed onto the box from the inside so that the strain relief stays on the inside. Screw the other half of the relief to the first one.
Might not be nuclearproof (=live gigproof) but seems to have worked for the past 4 months of near daily demo/practice use. This is what I used:
; layer_height = 0.35
; perimeters = 3
; top_solid_layers = 3
; bottom_solid_layers = 3
; fill_density = 0.8
; perimeter_speed = 30
; infill_speed = 60
; travel_speed = 130
; scale = 1
; nozzle_diameter = 0.35

Yet Another Spool. This was designed to leverage readily available and cheap materials in addition to 3D printabliciousness. In all likelihood this could be done with less plastic, shorter print times, etc. but as soon as I had a functioning spool for this 5 lbs. of PLA, it ceased to occupy any of my attention. In fact, I've been meaning to UL for a few weeks now, but have instead been not doing that. I had even thought of a few things which would qualify as fine tuning, but then I forgot most of them and ceased caring; what I could remember is now in the instructions, left as a challenge for You, my exceptional reader.

You will need a certain length of 1/2 inch dowel, #4 wood screws, and a 3 inch lazy susan bearing (I got mine off of mcmaster, but just today found that the local national hardware chain store (Ace) had them for, shockingly, about the same price). If you don't modify the scad file (which should make for entertaining/frightening reading) to have slightly larger dowel holes, you will probably need a 1/2 inch drill bit and something to bang on/with. If you do modify the script, you will probably actually have to use the countersunk holes I put in, which were designed for those semi-standard wood screws that one would get in bulk. Furthermore, if this latter route is the route you take, and you are a total nub (it happens), I'd recommend drilling pilot holes through the dowels. If you are modifying the script and intend to put a 5 lb. filament roll on this, I'd also recommend making the outermost teardrops a bit further apart; it's either struggle to compress the roll on there or struggle to parse my code--choose your own adventure!
Technical details aside, you will need (wait for it...) two of the hub halves. you will also need four of the other things, whatever I called them. The hubs were made to be stackable, either using multiple bearings or by running a dowel through the z axis. I recommend installing dowels on one half, installing the filament, then installing the other dowels. You will probably want to mount the spindle to something, and eventually a filament guide may be called for, though I've printed quite a lot with (surprisingly) zero spindle related problems.

title: Customizable Spool Bushing with Bearing options

description.text:
This is a customizable spool bushing that you can change the parameters. Nothing much about this but it does makes the spool rolls more smoothly on my spool stand pipe. I also included an option to have bearing slot. Just punch in the figures and there you have it. It seems like having rcount=10, have a bug in openscad where the 9th and 10th ring didn't show up, better avoid punching in 10 for rcount unless you want it The idea is actually from this guy http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:783215
I only made improvement of adding the option of customizing it so we all don't have to remodel a new thing whenever a different size for spool and stand mount were used Update 9th june 2015
Added option to remove the main hole (center) so that you can convert this into some kind of connector or anything. Another idea you can use this is to use the rings and slot in some threaded rod to make something vertical or as a pair. But main function was to use it as a spool bushing for my geeetech filament spool stand to make it smooth Update 10th June 2015
Changed the ring position formula so that it will always stays in between inner wall and outer wall of the bushing no matter how you change the inner and outer diameter. Remember to properly set your parameters

Everything is in metric value. Measure up your spool hole and your mount diameter and punch in to the inner and outer. Leave some gaps by about 0.5-1mm depending on your printer, if yours has wobble, make that a minimum of 1mm larger/smaller The rings to provide lesser plastic usage at the same time providing more rigid structure because it's a cylinder. Adjust the rcount to how many rings you want along with the rsize. You can slot in any kind of rods in the ring slot too to make something else =D Enable bearing if you want to use bearing with your own setup. measure your desired bearing to be used, height and outer diameter and punch it in as well I printed mine with these parameter and this object also suitable to be printed in pla too

To get the two color print I printed the first few layers in red, paused the print and used white until the numbers started printing (or after the "writing area" was done in the case of the blank designs) then paused and switched back to red for the rest of the print.

author: jcallinan

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/56BPbU9CN8n I made these to fit my daughter's Playskool gear toy. It's her favorite toy and the gears disappear faster than socks.
For each one of your sins, we've prepared an agonizing and ironic punishment! Beelzebot, The Robot Devil.

Here's Beezlebot:) I'll give some tips for printing that helped me.
First, I found that due to the small size of the parts, it's important to use a high quality filament, one that sticks to itself well, and not brittle. The model prints with no support in the positions I've uploaded. The tradeoff for this is there are flat spots in some areas where they touch the print bed. If you rotate them, I found they don't print as strong. I had to think of them as being made out of wood and tried to get the print head to run with the form and make the pieces the strongest they could be.
I've used the naming convention of adding a number after to show how many pieces of that particular part needs to be printed.
The links (link21) are tight and if there is a problem, try running an Exacto around the inside of the cup gently and see if they snap together easier-it is wise to print a few spares. They were made this way to be true to the cartoon and still be articulated.
The teeth and the neck of the violin need to be glued in place. The horns can be glued as well, there is not a lot of meat on the clips.
The mouth uses detents cut into the head for an open or closed position.
The tail can be made two ways. You can print out whip tail and be finished or use tailpt and add a small wire for the tail section to make it poseable.
Foota uses ankles. Footb uses links. If you go with footb, you do not need to print ankles. I tried to stay true to the cartoon, so I gave you the option of which one you want to use. Foota has more mobility at the cost of not being true to the cartoon.
Firstlink is what you will use where the limbs attach to the body, 2 at the shoulders, and 2 at the hips.
Necklink attaches to one link21 and connects the head to the body.
Fryhands are broken into 2 models, fryhanda and fryhandb. Each of these have a left and right. The difference between them is one has a cuff.
Linkspinetorso attaches to spineshortorso and connects the pelvis to the body.
I used 4 of link21 for each arm,6 of link21 for each leg(with footb), and the last link is used for the neck assembly.
If there is any confusion, check out the photo or leave me a comment.
If you're on Instagram, please follow me, Simonarri.
